The Guarded Domains of Iran,[lower-alpha 1] commonly called Safavid Iran, Safavid Persia[lower-alpha 2] or the Safavid Empire,[lower-alpha 3] was one of the largest and long-standing Iranian empires after the 7th-century Muslim conquest of Persia. It was ruled from 1501 to 1736 by the Safavid dynasty.[24][25][26][27] It is often considered the beginning of modern Iranian history,[28] as well as one of the gunpowder empires.[29] The Safavid Shāh Ismā'īl I established the Twelver denomination of Shīʿa Islam as the official religion of the empire, marking one of the most important turning points in the history of Islam.[30]

An Iranian dynasty rooted in the Sufi Safavid order[31] founded by Kurdish sheikhs,[32] it heavily intermarried with Turkoman,[33] Georgian,[34] Circassian, and Pontic Greek[37] dignitaries and was Turkish-speaking and Turkified.[38] From their base in Ardabil, the Safavids established control over parts of Greater Iran and reasserted the Iranian identity of the region,[39] thus becoming the first native dynasty since the Buyids to establish a national state officially known as Iran.[40]

The Safavids ruled from 1501 to 1722 (experiencing a brief restoration from 1729 to 1736 and 1750 to 1773) and, at their height, they controlled all of what is now Iran, Republic of Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Armenia, eastern Georgia, parts of the North Caucasus including Russia, Iraq, Kuwait, and Afghanistan, as well as parts of Turkey, Syria, Pakistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan.
